awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Biocultural dynamics of the postpartum interval
awd_abstract_narration:
In biocultural research, anthropologists are interested in the complex interactions between biology and culture that occur throughout the human lifecourse. One important part of the lifecourse is the time immediately following the birth of a child, when mothers experience physiological changes, may be vulnerable to various stressors, and potentially receive help from other individuals. This doctoral dissertation research examines the relationships between maternal postpartum depression, culturally relevant social support, and maternal levels of the hormone oxytocin, to better understand the postpartum period from a biocultural perspective. The project will advance fundamental knowledge about maternal dynamics and the biocultural nature of our species. The research may also have broader public health impact by informing culturally appropriate interventions for improving postpartum maternal health. In addition, the project will support graduate training, international research collaborations, and community science outreach. 

A cooperative breeding model has been used to describe patterns of infant care in humans. Mothers especially benefit from help during the immediate postpartum when the stress of caring for an altricial infant co-occurs with physical recovery from pregnancy. This project focuses on maternal characteristics in the immediate postpartum, thereby extending beyond previous work that focused largely on reproductive fitness and infant outcomes. Following a cohort of women who share cultural expectations regarding postpartum support, this study will examine whether greater discordance between received and expected social support in the postpartum is related to maternal depressive symptoms, and whether oxytocin and social support levels are related. The project will characterize local cultural expectations of social support via interviews with women. A group of 150 pregnant women will be interviewed during their third trimester, and again approximately 40 days postpartum to determine congruence between received support (reported and directly observed) and cultural expectations of social support, depressive symptoms, and urine oxytocin levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to better understand the link between maternal mental health and the culturally relevant social support provided by postpartum practices. This work provides the basis for expansion of the cooperative breeding model to include maternal mental health in the immediate postpartum contextualized within cultural variations in valued social support. To do this, my work began with ethnography to identify the cultural model of ideal postpartum social support (i.e., the cuarentena) in Coatepec, Veracruz, Mexico, as well as face-validate the scales used to measure postpartum depressive symptoms and maternal perceptions of infant health. Subsequently, the major portion of my research examined whether adherence to the cultural model in the immediate postpartum was associated with fewer depressive symptoms when controlling for infant health. Use of the locally relevant instruments allowed me not only to capture the presence/absence of help received but also the amount of help and women’s perceptions/feelings about the help recieved. Hence, I was able not only to describe what was ‘done’ by supporters but also how that help was ‘experienced’ by the new mothers—crucial information considering that not all help is considered valuable nor protective of mental health.

The onset of the global pandemic not only disrupted some of my study plans, but also allowed me the opportunity for a post-hoc exploration of how the COVID-19 public health mandates affected maternal mood and postpartum experiences including the ability to practice the cuarentena.

Overall, the data from both my initial design and the COVID-19 post-hoc addition, showed that the cuarentena in Coatepec is highly valued, widely practiced, and requires a great deal of help from others, primarily female relatives. The ability to practice the cuarentena, along with its inherent social support, reportedly made women feel good. Although the association between cultural model adherence and postpartum depressive symptoms was not statistically significant, mean postpartum depressive scores were higher for women who felt that they only practiced the cuarentena “a little” compared to those who perceived themselves to have practiced “a lot.” Furthermore, despite the COVID-19 pandemic, most women followed their original cuarentena plans with only minor modifications—even when doing so contradicted public health mandates. When the women did adjust cuarentena practices to adhere to mandates that limited socialization with friends and extended family, maternal mood was negatively affected.

These results demonstrate the importance of expanding the cooperative breeding model to incorporate maternal mental health and valued social support as it is culturally defined. It was not simply the presence/absence of support that affected maternal mental health, as typically measured by cooperative breeding researchers. Rather, it was the presence of valued support delivered by those perceived as important that contributed to maternal well-being. Given these findings and the potentially severe consequences of impaired mental health while mothers are tending neonates, it is imperative that cooperative breeding researchers expand their focus to include cultural considerations during the postpartum period.

This project furthers our ability to minimize risk for poor postpartum mental health by deepening clinical understanding of the interaction between mothers’ cultural context and lived experience. Current solutions to maternal distress tend to be Western biomedicine-based in that they focus exclusively on addressing the depressive symptoms with medication or psychotherapy but overlook the sociocultural context that may be both a critical source of the problem or key to the solution. We shared the results of this study with the clinic staff and participants. It is hoped that this knowledge will help identify risks for poor postpartum mental health and help develop culturally appropriate interventions. Finally, this project helped a doctoral student earn her PhD, and provided training for a local Mexican woman who worked as a research assistant who used the experience to gain admittance to a competitive Master’s in Public Health program in Mexico.
